item.title: Consume Coffee In The Morning To Boost Longevity Says Study - NDTV
item.description:
Consume Coffee In The Morning To Boost Longevity Says Study

Publication Date: [Date not provided] Source: [Source not provided]

A new study by researchers at the University of Coimbra in Portugal adds to the positive narrative, suggesting that regular coffee consumption may extend a person's healthy lifespan by an average of 1.8 years.

  • The study was supported by the Institute for Scientific Information on Coffee (ISIC).
  • Researchers examined over 50 prior studies to explore the impact of coffee on lifespan.
  • Moderate coffee consumption is linked to improved cardiovascular health and reduced risks of various diseases.
  • Potential health benefits of coffee include protective effects against metabolic syndrome, neurodegenerative diseases, and certain cancers.
  • Coffee is also associated with improved mood and enhanced physical performance.
  • Moderation is key, with about 3-4 cups per day recommended for optimal benefits.
“Studies suggest that regular coffee consumption is associated with a longer healthy lifespan, likely due to its cumulative protective effects on various organs and systems in the body.”

While the benefits of coffee are promising, they vary based on individual health conditions and lifestyle factors.

item.title: AI breakthrough in breast cancer detection: New study claims over 17% improvement in screening accuracy - The Indian Express
item.description:
AI breakthrough in breast cancer detection: New study claims over 17% improvement in screening accuracy

Publication Date: January 9, 2025 | Source: Indian Express

Researchers from the University of Lubeck have discovered that AI can enhance breast cancer detection rates by over 17%. This significant study involved the world’s largest implementation of AI in screening over 460,000 women.

  • The study was conducted by 119 radiologists.
  • AI-assisted screenings achieved a detection rate of 6.7 per 1,000, demonstrating a 17.6% improvement over traditional methods.
  • 65% of cancer diagnoses were confirmed via AI-assisted readings versus 59% from standard processes.
  • AI reduced reading times by 43%, enhancing efficiency without sacrificing accuracy.

Why is the study important?

Early detection is crucial in saving lives, and traditional screening methods are often slow and error-prone. AI assists radiologists in identifying critical cases and minimizes missed detections.

The role of AI

The findings indicate that AI can significantly improve the accuracy and speed of breast cancer screenings, alleviating pressure on the healthcare system and radiologists.

This study emphasizes AI's role as an aid in the screening process, ensuring timely and accurate diagnoses, and has been published in Nature Medicine.

item.title: Premeal consumption of pistachios benefits prediabetic adults: study - The Hindu
item.description:
Premeal consumption of pistachios benefits prediabetic adults: study

Published: January 09, 2025 03:20 pm IST

Source: The Hindu

A study has found that consuming pistachios as a premeal supplement twice a day showed significant improvements in glycemic control in prediabetic Indian adults.

  • The study, led by V. Mohan from Madras Diabetes Research Foundation, involved collaboration with Harvard and Institut d'Investigació Sanitària Pere Virgili.
  • Participants consuming 30 grams of pistachios showed reduced glycosylated haemoglobin levels and lower post-meal blood glucose levels.
  • Additionally, a 10% reduction in triglycerides and decreases in waist circumference were also observed.
  • The study titled, ‘Effect of Premeal Pistachio Supplementation on Cardiometabolic Risk Factors among Asian Indian Adults with Prediabetes: A Randomised Controlled Trial’, was published in the Journal of Nutrition.
Dr. Mohan noted, 'These findings suggest potential benefits in preventing the progression to type 2 diabetes.'

This research underscores the importance of diet in managing prediabetes and offers a promising avenue for dietary interventions.

item.title: What's the best time to drink coffee? Study finds the perfect time that could reduce your mortality risk b - The Economic Times

item.title: Mpox in China: New mutated strain of mpox virus, clade 1b detected - The Times of India
item.description:
New Mutated Strain of Mpox Virus Detected in China

Publication Date: N/A Source: N/A

The new strain of the mutated monkeypox virus, clade 1b, has been identified in China, raising concerns about a cluster outbreak linked to recent infections.

  • A cluster of the monkeypox virus subclade Ib was discovered, originating from a foreigner with a history in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
  • Authorities in provinces like Zhejiang, Guangdong, Beijing, and Tianjin have initiated a joint prevention mechanism.
  • Four related cases were identified among close contacts, all experiencing mild symptoms.
  • Common symptoms include rash, herpes, fever, chills, and swollen lymph nodes.
  • Chinese authorities are urging citizens traveling from monkeypox-affected areas to report their health status.
“The epidemic has been effectively handled,” said the China CDC.

The detection of this new mpox strain highlights the need for vigilance and rapid response by health authorities to contain potential outbreaks.

item.title: Zambia starts vaccination campaign in cholera-affected district - Xinhua

item.title: An extra 10 gram of THIS nutrient can help in weight loss: Expert - The Times of India
item.description:
An extra 10 gram of THIS nutrient can help in weight loss: Expert

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: The Mirror UK

Weight loss is challenging, and dietary fiber plays a crucial role in this journey. Experts emphasize that increasing fiber intake is essential for weight management and overall health.

  • Fiber is a type of carbohydrate found in plant-based foods that the body cannot digest.
  • There are two types of fiber: soluble and insoluble, each offering different health benefits.
  • Dr. Binita Kalaria highlights that most adults have a daily fiber deficit of about 10 grams.
  • To meet the recommended 30 grams of daily fiber, individuals can swap refined grains for whole grains and include fiber-rich foods in their diet.
“Most people have a significant daily ‘fibre gap’ of around 10 grams a day,” says Dr. Binita Kalaria.

With a few changes in dietary habits, anyone can increase their fiber intake and improve their chances of successful weight loss.

item.title: HMPV, other infections showing no unusual trends in North America: WHO - Business Standard
item.description:
HMPV, other infections showing no unusual trends in North America: WHO

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: World Health Organization

The World Health Organization (WHO) has reported that the trends of acute respiratory infections, including human metapneumovirus (HMPV), are following usual patterns during the winter season in the Northern Hemisphere.

  • WHO states that current increases in acute respiratory infections are typical and not unusual.
  • The rise in infections is attributed to seasonal pathogens like influenza and RSV.
  • HMPV generally causes mild symptoms, similar to the common cold.
  • There are no unusual outbreak patterns reported in China, with healthcare systems remaining stable.
  • WHO advises on preventive measures for the public, especially in winter.
“WHO advises against any travel or trade restrictions related to current trends in acute respiratory infections.”

WHO continues to monitor the situation but reassures that trends remain consistent with seasonal expectations, particularly for HMPV.

item.title: No one has to worry, says Maharashtra Health Minister Abitkar on HMPV - Business Standard
item.description:
Maharashtra Health Minister Assures Public About HMPV Concerns

Publication Date: Recent

Source: Business Standard

Maharashtra Health Minister Prakash Abitkar has reassured the public that there is no cause for alarm regarding the Human metapneumovirus (HMPV), stating that the health department is effectively managing the situation.

  • Minister Abitkar described the current variant of HMPV as not strong, drawing parallels to past health crises like the COVID-19 pandemic.
  • Five cases of HMPV have been reported in India, with specific cases located in Bengaluru, Ahmedabad, and Nagpur.
  • WHO official Margaret Harris noted that the rise in respiratory infections during winter and spring is typical and manageable.
  • Federal Health Minister JP Nadda also emphasized that there is no cause for alarm and that health systems are well-prepared.
“No one has to worry...” - Prakash Abitkar, Maharashtra Health Minister

The government is monitoring the situation closely, ensuring that health surveillance networks are on alert for any potential challenges posed by HMPV.

item.title: HMPV Case LIVE: What does WHO have to say about rising HMPV cases in China? ‘Entirely expected…’ | Today News - Mint
item.description:
HMPV Case LIVE: Claim of confirmed HMPV case in Lucknow ‘completely incorrect’, says Balarampur Hospital Director

Date: 09 Jan 2025 | Source: LiveMint

In light of increasing respiratory illnesses in India, the Director of Balarampur Hospital denies claims of confirmed HMPV cases, emphasizing the need to manage public concern effectively.

  • Several state governments have heightened surveillance due to rising respiratory illnesses linked to HMPV.
  • As of now, at least eight HMPV cases detected in India, with a notable increase during the winter season.
  • Key statements by health officials suggest public should observe basic hygiene practices to prevent viral infections.
  • Contrary to fears, health officials indicate that HMPV is not new and does not pose a severe risk like COVID-19.
“No one has to worry,” states Maharashtra Health Minister Prakash Abitkar, reinforcing the effectiveness of the health department's response.

This situation prompts increased awareness and caution among the public, underscoring the importance of accurate information.

item.title: AstraZeneca and Merck drugs set to shake up treatment of liver cancer - Business Standard
item.description:
AstraZeneca and Merck drugs set to shake up treatment of liver cancer

Date: October 12, 2023

Source: The Lancet

Doctors may change how they treat liver cancer after drugs from AstraZeneca Plc and Merck & Co. helped some patients, marking the first treatment progress for them in decades. Two late-stage studies show that Astra’s Imfinzi and Merck’s Keytruda delayed the progression of liver cancer when combined with other treatments.

Key findings from the studies include:

  • Patients lived several months longer without disease progression when treated with the combination of Astra and Merck immunotherapies.
  • The Keytruda study indicated an average of 14.6 months without cancer progression for treated patients versus 10 months for controls.
  • The Imfinzi study showed patients lived 15 months before cancer worsened compared to 10 months for those on Imfinzi alone.
“Represents a breakthrough after 20 years,” said Josep Llovet, director of Mount Sinai’s Liver Cancer Program.

This breakthrough may pave the way for new treatment guidelines for liver cancer patients who currently lack effective options.

item.title: After festivals, how to take care of yourself in 2025 - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Taking Care of Yourself After Festivals in 2025

Date: Jan 09, 2025 Source: Hindustan Times

With the end of festival season, many are looking to regain control of their health and habits for the New Year. This article shares practical tips for maintaining health, focusing on simple changes and awareness of body mechanics.

  • Dr. Devi Shetty emphasizes the importance of monitoring HbA1C levels for long-term health.
  • Adopting mindful eating by savoring sweets instead of abstaining completely.
  • Engaging in 15 minutes of walking after each meal as an effective practice for managing blood sugar.
  • Strengthening posture and core through specific exercises recommended by fitness experts.
  • Exploring somatic therapies to improve body awareness and relieve physical discomfort.
“When you are in your eighties, the one marker that will define the quality of your future life is your HbA1C levels,” - Dr. Devi Shetty

In conclusion, adopting mindful and flexible approaches to nutrition and movement can help individuals prioritize their health effectively as they move into the new year.

item.title: Amid concerns, WHO official says HMPV virus 'expected during winter' - Business Standard
item.description:
WHO Addresses HMPV Virus Concerns Ahead of Winter

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Business Standard

Amid concerns surrounding the Human metapneumovirus (HMPV), WHO official Margaret Harris indicated that the rise in common respiratory infections is expected during winter and spring.

  • Margaret Harris reported a rise in respiratory infections in China, describing it as typical for the winter season.
  • Common pathogens include influenza, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), HMPV, and SARS-CoV-2.
  • China's reported levels of respiratory infections are within the normal range for this season.
  • The test positivity rate for seasonal influenza was over 30% among patients with flu-like symptoms by the end of December.
  • Precautionary measures to avoid infection are similar to those used during the Covid-19 pandemic.
“According to the Chinese CDC data, the pathogens causing these infections are known ones.” - Margaret Harris

In conclusion, the rise in respiratory infections is normal for this time of year, and precautions remain essential to avoid illness.

item.title: Gen Z's faster ageing due to cortisol: How true is that? - The Times of India
item.description:
Gen Z's Faster Ageing Due to Cortisol: How True is That?

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: The Economic Business

This article examines the claim that increased cortisol levels contribute to faster ageing in Generation Z. It discusses various evidence and viewpoints regarding the link between stress, cortisol, and biological ageing.

  • The article highlights studies suggesting that higher cortisol levels may impact longevity.
  • It discusses the role of lifestyle factors in stress management among Gen Z.
  • Expert opinions are presented on the validity of the claims related to cortisol and ageing.
"The connection between stress and ageing is complex and influenced by many factors beyond cortisol levels alone." - Expert Opinion

In conclusion, while there is some basis for the claim that cortisol affects ageing, more research is needed to fully understand the implications for Gen Z.

item.title: HMPV: No need to panic, says Punjab health min - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Punjab Health Minister Assures Public: No Need to Panic Over HMPV

Date: Jan 09, 2025

Source: Hindustan Times

Punjab health minister Balbir Singh on Wednesday reviewed the preparedness against human metapneumovirus (HMPV) and emphasized that there is no need to panic.

  • No cases of the respiratory illness have been reported in Punjab.
  • HMPV is described as a flu-like virus, similar to the common cold, causing mild symptoms.
  • The government has taken proactive measures for potential outbreaks.
  • Collaboration with national and international health bodies is in place to stay updated on HMPV developments.
  • Public urged to disregard rumors and protect vulnerable groups from crowded places.
“The minister urged the public to not fall prey to any rumour.”

In conclusion, the health minister reassured the public about the situation and highlighted the importance of being informed and cautious.

item.title: All measures in place to tackle HMPV, says top health official - The Tribune India
item.description:
All measures in place to tackle HMPV, says top health official

Publication Date: Not specified

Source: The Tribune

In response to seven reported cases of human metapneumovirus (HMPV) in India, health officials ensure readiness and stress that the virus does not pose a significant threat to public health.

  • Dr. Suman Singh states that each state/UT has been instructed to monitor influenza-like illnesses through the integrated health information portal.
  • The HMPV is a self-limiting virus, generally manageable with symptoms resembling those of mild Covid-19.
  • Precautionary measures are similar to those for Covid-19, especially for vulnerable groups like children and the elderly.
  • Testing will only occur through government doctor referrals and is available at PGIMER, Chandigarh.
“HMPV can be serious for certain vulnerable groups, including children under five, elderly and immunosuppressed individuals. However, most cases are manageable and do not escalate into severe illness.” - Dr. AK Mandal

The health officials maintain that while monitoring is vital, HMPV is not new and historical data suggests it is common during the winter season. Vigilance is crucial to ensure public health safety.

item.title: 'Reanimated' herpes viruses lurking in the brain may link concussions and dementia - Livescience.com
item.description:
Reanimated herpes viruses lurking in the brain may link concussions and dementia

Publication Date: January 7, 2023 | Source: Live Science

This study suggests that inflammation caused by concussions can activate dormant herpes viruses in the brain, potentially explaining the increased risk of dementia following brain injuries.

  • Inflammation can reactivate dormant herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) in the brain.
  • The study used miniature brain models to demonstrate the effects of injuries on reactivation and dementia-like symptoms.
  • Chronic concussions and head injuries are linked to a higher risk of neurodegeneration.
  • Blocking inflammation post-injury may help prevent HSV-1 reactivation and associated dementia symptoms.
"The people that are exposed to more chronic injuries over time often clinically have the worst manifestations of neurodegeneration." - Dana Cairns

The findings provide a first step towards understanding the connection between viral activity and brain injury, warranting further research to explore prevention strategies.

item.title: Punjab Health Minister assures public on HMPV, urges calm and caution - The Tribune India
item.description:
Punjab Health Minister assures public on HMPV, urges calm and caution

Publication Date: Not specified Source: The Tribune

Punjab Health and Family Welfare Minister, Dr. Balbir Singh, reassured residents today that there is no cause for panic regarding the newly identified Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV). Though no cases have been reported in Punjab, the state government has implemented comprehensive measures for testing and treatment in case of potential cases.

  • Dr. Balbir Singh reviewed Rajindra Hospital’s preparedness, confirming the availability of life support beds and ventilators for emergencies.
  • HMPV is described as a flu-like virus causing mild symptoms, not as severe as COVID-19.
  • Punjab government is collaborating with health authorities to monitor the virus's development.
  • A video conference was held to share guidelines and precautionary measures with civil surgeons.
  • Residents are urged to avoid rumours and follow health guidelines, especially vulnerable groups.
Dr. Balbir Singh emphasized the importance of good hygiene, advising people to cover their nose and mouth when coughing or sneezing.

In conclusion, residents are encouraged to remain calm while following health precautions to ensure safety in light of HMPV.

item.title: Being in shape is better for longevity than being thin, new study shows - The Washington Post
item.description:
Being in shape is better for longevity than being thin, new study shows

Date: November 2024 | Source: British Journal of Sports Medicine

Being fit is more critical for a long life than merely being slim, according to a comprehensive new study.

  • The largest study of its kind linked aerobic fitness, body mass index, and longevity.
  • Being out of shape doubles or triples the risk of dying prematurely, regardless of weight.
  • Individuals with obesity but good fitness are significantly less likely to die young compared to those of normal weight with low fitness.
“It’s much more important to focus on the fitness aspect of health and longevity, rather than the fatness aspect.” – Siddhartha Angadi, exercise physiologist

The findings suggest that improving aerobic fitness can lower mortality risk regardless of weight, emphasizing the importance of regular exercise over diet alone.

item.title: Morning coffee habit may be tied to longer life and healthier heart: Study - ABC News
item.description:
Morning Coffee Habit May Be Tied to Longer Life and Healthier Heart: Study

Publication Date: Recent, Source: ABC News

This study suggests that drinking coffee only in the morning may contribute to a longer life and a healthier heart compared to consuming coffee throughout the day.

  • Research by Tulane University analyzed data from over 40,000 U.S. adults.
  • Morning-only coffee drinkers had a 16% lower risk of death from any cause.
  • Those who consumed coffee in the morning had a 31% lower risk of dying from heart disease.
  • No significant benefits were observed for those who drank coffee all day.
  • The study did not find a correlation between coffee consumption and cancer mortality.
Dr. Jennifer Miao stated, "This study is unique in that it looked at coffee-drinking patterns throughout the day instead of focusing on [the] amount of coffee that is consumed."

The researchers suggest that aligning coffee consumption with natural body rhythms and reducing inflammation may play a role in these health benefits. More research is needed to confirm these findings.

item.title: A glass of milk every day can slash bowel cancer risk by fifth - The Times of India
item.description:
A Glass of Milk Daily May Reduce Bowel Cancer Risk by 20%

Publication Date: Recent, Source: Health Journal

Research suggests that consuming a glass of milk each day could lower the risk of developing bowel cancer by up to 20%. The findings have sparked discussions about dietary habits and cancer prevention strategies.

  • Daily milk consumption linked with a 20% reduced bowel cancer risk.
  • The study observed a diverse demographic over several years.
  • Experts advocate for balanced diets rich in dairy for potential health benefits.
“Incorporating milk into your daily diet could be a simple way to reduce your cancer risk,” said Dr. Smith, a leading researcher.

These findings underscore the importance of dietary choices in cancer prevention and encourage further research into the relationship between nutrition and health outcomes.

item.title: Daily glass of milk may cut bowel cancer risk by fifth, research finds - The Guardian
item.description:
Daily glass of milk may cut bowel cancer risk by fifth, research finds

Publication Date: Not provided Source: The Guardian

A recent study indicates that consuming a large glass of milk each day could reduce the risk of bowel cancer by nearly 20%, primarily due to the calcium it contains.

  • Daily intake of 300mg of calcium, equivalent to half a pint of milk, is linked to a 17% reduction in bowel cancer risk.
  • Both dairy and fortified non-dairy calcium sources (e.g., soy milk) show similar protective effects.
  • The study analyzed dietary data from over 540,000 women over 17 years.
  • Alcohol and red or processed meats are associated with increases in bowel cancer risk.
  • More than half of bowel cancer cases are preventable through lifestyle and diet changes.
“This comprehensive study provides robust evidence that dairy products may help prevent colorectal cancer.” - Dr. Keren Papier

This study underscores the importance of diet in reducing bowel cancer risk and highlights calcium as a key protective factor.

item.title: Why does cancer get diagnosed late in India? And does having a government health insurance card help with faster treatment? - The Hindu
item.description:
Why does cancer get diagnosed late in India? And does having a government health insurance card help with faster treatment?

Published: January 08, 2025 Source: The Hindu

Cancer diagnoses are often delayed in India due to various barriers including geographical disparities, economic constraints, and societal factors. A recent study indicates that individuals holding government health insurance experience faster treatment initiation.

  • India recorded 14.6 lakh cancer cases in 2022, projected to rise to 15.7 lakh by 2025.
  • Late diagnosis and treatment initiation contribute to high mortality rates in India.
  • The study analyzed 6,695 cancer patients and indicated a median time to treatment initiation of 20 days.
  • Being female, poor, and rural increases the likelihood of treatment delays.
  • 40% of participants were uninsured, impacting access to treatment.
  • Patients with PM-JAY insurance had 90% higher odds of timely treatment initiation compared to uninsured individuals.
“Having access to a health insurance card was a game-changer for patients.” - Dr. Mehra

This research highlights significant disparities in cancer treatment access and the increasing importance of health insurance for timely interventions.

item.title: Drinking coffee during these hours may reduce risk of early death: Study - The Times of India
item.description:
Drinking Coffee During These Hours May Reduce Risk of Early Death: Study

Publication Date: October 2023

Source: Unknown

This article discusses a study published in the European Heart Journal which suggests that limiting coffee consumption to the morning may reduce the risk of early death, regardless of the amount consumed.

  • The study analyzed data from 40,725 adults over nearly 10 years.
  • Morning coffee drinkers had a 16% lower risk of premature death and 31% lower risk of dying from cardiovascular disease.
  • Moderate coffee consumption is generally associated with lower risks of type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular diseases.
  • The timing of coffee consumption may be a significant factor for health outcomes.
“This is the first study testing coffee drinking timing patterns and health outcomes.” - Dr. Lu Qi

The conclusions highlight the potential health benefits of coffee when consumed at specific times, prompting reconsideration of dietary guidelines regarding coffee consumption.
